    <TD noWrap align=left width="1%" bgColor=#c0c0c0></TD>
    <TD noWrap align=left width="3%" bgColor=#c0c0c0></TD>
    <TD style="TEXT-ALIGN: center" noWrap width="1%" bgColor=#c0c0c0></TD>
    <TD style="TEXT-ALIGN: center" noWrap width="3%" bgColor=#c0c0c0><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>x</FONT></TD>
    <TD noWrap align=left width="1%" bgColor=#c0c0c0></TD>
    <TD noWrap align=left width="3%" bgColor=#c0c0c0></TD>
    <TD style="TEXT-ALIGN: center" noWrap width="1%" bgColor=#c0c0c0></TD>
    <TD style="TEXT-ALIGN: center" noWrap width="3%" bgColor=#c0c0c0><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Chair</FONT></TD>
    <TD noWrap align=left width="1%" bgColor=#c0c0c0></TD>
    <TD noWrap align=left width="3%" bgColor=#c0c0c0></TD></TR>
  <TR vAlign=bottom>
    <TD noWrap align=left width="80%"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Ronald L. Sargent</FONT></TD>
    <TD style="TEXT-ALIGN: center" noWrap width="1%"></TD>
    <TD style="TEXT-ALIGN: center" noWrap width="3%"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Chair</FONT></TD>
    <TD noWrap align=left width="1%"></TD>
    <TD noWrap align=left width="3%"></TD>
    <TD noWrap align=left width="1%"></TD>
    <TD noWrap align=left width="3%"></TD>
    <TD noWrap align=left width="1%"></TD>
    <TD noWrap align=left width="3%"></TD>
    <TD style="TEXT-ALIGN: center" noWrap width="1%"></TD>
    <TD style="TEXT-ALIGN: center" noWrap width="3%"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>x</FONT></TD></TR>
  <TR vAlign=bottom>
    <TD noWrap align=left width="80%" bgColor=#c0c0c0><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Bobby S. Shackouls</FONT></TD>
    <TD style="TEXT-ALIGN: center" noWrap width="1%" bgColor=#c0c0c0></TD>
    <TD style="TEXT-ALIGN: center" noWrap width="3%" bgColor=#c0c0c0><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>x</FONT></TD>
    <TD noWrap align=left width="1%" bgColor=#c0c0c0></TD>
    <TD noWrap align=left width="3%" bgColor=#c0c0c0></TD>
    <TD style="TEXT-ALIGN: center" noWrap width="1%" bgColor=#c0c0c0></TD>
    <TD style="TEXT-ALIGN: center" noWrap width="3%" bgColor=#c0c0c0><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>x</FONT></TD>
    <TD noWrap align=left width="1%" bgColor=#c0c0c0></TD>
    <TD noWrap align=left width="3%" bgColor=#c0c0c0></TD>
    <TD noWrap align=left width="1%" bgColor=#c0c0c0></TD>
    <TD noWrap align=left width="3%" bgColor=#c0c0c0></TD></TR></TABLE><BR>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=3>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; </FONT>During 2013, the
Audit Committee met five times, the Compensation Committee met four times, and
the Corporate Governance Committee met two times. The Audit Committee reviews
financial reporting and accounting matters pursuant to its charter and selects
our independent accountants. The Compensation Committee recommends for
determination by the independent members of our Board the compensation of the
Chief Executive Officer, determines the compensation of Kroger&#146;s other senior
management, and administers some of our incentive programs. Additional
information on the Compensation Committee&#146;s processes and procedures for
consideration of executive compensation are addressed in the Compensation
Discussion and Analysis below. The Corporate Governance Committee develops
criteria for selecting and retaining members of the Board, seeks out qualified
candidates for the Board, and reviews the performance of the Board and, along
with the other independent board members, the CEO.</FONT></P>


<P STYLE="text-align: left"><B><FONT style="FONT-VARIANT: small-caps" face="Times New Roman" size=2>Director Nominations</FONT></B></P>

<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=3>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; </FONT>The Corporate
Governance Committee will consider shareholder recommendations for nominees for
membership on the Board of Directors. If shareholders wish to nominate a person
or persons for election to the Board of Directors at our 2015 annual meeting,
written notice must be submitted to the Company&#146;s Secretary, and received at our
executive offices not later than January 14, 2015. Such notice should include
the name, age, business address and residence address of such person, the
principal occupation or employment of such person, the number of shares of the
Company owned of record or beneficially by such person, and any other
information relating to the person that would be required to be included in a
proxy statement relating to the election of directors. The Secretary will
forward the information to the Corporate Governance Committee for its
consideration. The Committee will use the same criteria in evaluating candidates
submitted by shareholders as it uses in evaluating candidates identified by the
Committee. These criteria are:</FONT></P>
<UL style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt">
  <LI STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Demonstrated ability in fields
  considered to be of value in the deliberations of the Board, including</FONT>
  <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>business management, public service,
  education, science, law, and government;<BR>&nbsp;</FONT></LI>
  <LI STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Highest standards of personal
  character and conduct;</FONT></LI></UL>
<P align=center><B><FONT face="Times New Roman">15</FONT></B></P>
<HR align=center width="100%" noShade SIZE=2>

<DIV style="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: always"></DIV><BR>
<UL style="FONT-SIZE: 8pt">
  <LI STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Willingness to fulfill the obligations
  of directors and to make the contribution of which he or she is
  capable,</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>including regular
  attendance and participation at Board and committee meetings, and preparation
  for all</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>meetings, including review
  of all meeting materials provided in advance of the meeting;
  and<BR>&nbsp;</FONT></LI>
  <LI STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Ability to understand the perspectives
  of Kroger&#146;s customers, taking into consideration the diversity of</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>our customers, including regional and geographic
  differences.</FONT> </LI></UL>
<P align=justify>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Racial, ethnic, and gender diversity is an important element in promoting
full, open, and balanced deliberations of issues presented to the Board, and is
considered by the Corporate Governance Committee. Some consideration also is
given to the geographic location of director candidates in order to provide a
reasonable distribution of members from the operating areas of the
Company.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=3>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; </FONT>The Corporate
Governance Committee typically recruits candidates for Board membership through
its own efforts and through suggestions from other directors and shareholders.
The Committee on occasion has retained an outside search firm to assist in
identifying and recruiting Board candidates who meet the criteria established by
the Committee.</FONT></P>


<P STYLE="text-align: left"><B><FONT style="FONT-VARIANT: small-caps" face="Times New Roman" size=2>Corporate Governance</FONT></B></P>

<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=3>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; </FONT>The Board of
Directors has adopted </FONT><I><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Guidelines
on Issues of Corporate Governance</FONT></I><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>. These </FONT><I><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Guidelines</FONT></I><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>, which include
copies of the current charters for the Audit, Compensation, and Corporate
Governance Committees, and the other committees of the Board of Directors, are
available on our corporate website at ir.kroger.com. Shareholders may obtain a
copy of the </FONT><I><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Guidelines</FONT></I><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2> by making a
written request to Kroger&#146;s Secretary at our executive offices.</FONT></P>

<P STYLE="text-align: left"><B><FONT style="FONT-VARIANT: small-caps" face="Times New Roman" size=2>Independence</FONT></B></P>


<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=3>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; </FONT>The Board of
Directors has determined that all of the directors, with the exception of
Messrs. Dillon and McMullen, have no material relationships with Kroger and,
therefore, are independent for purposes of the New York Stock Exchange listing
standards. The Board made its determination based on information furnished by
all members regarding their relationships with Kroger and its management, and
other relevant information. After reviewing the information, the Board
determined that all of the non-employee directors were independent because (i)
they all satisfied the independence standards set forth in Rule 10A-3 of the
Securities Exchange Act of 1934, (ii) they all satisfied the criteria for
independence set forth in Rule 303A.02 of the New York Stock Exchange Listed
Company Manual, (iii) any business transactions between Kroger and entities with
which the directors are affiliated, the value of which falls below the
thresholds identified by the New York Stock Exchange listing standards, and (iv)
none had any material relationships with us except for those arising directly
from their performance of services as a director for Kroger.</FONT></P>


<P STYLE="text-align: left"><B><FONT style="FONT-VARIANT: small-caps" face="Times New Roman" size=2>Audit Committee Expertise</FONT></B></P>


<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=3>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; </FONT>The Board of
Directors has determined that Susan M. Phillips and Ronald L. Sargent,
independent directors who are members of the Audit Committee, are &#147;audit
committee financial experts&#148; as defined by applicable SEC regulations and that
all members of the Audit Committee are &#147;financially literate&#148; as that term is
used in the NYSE listing standards.</FONT></P>


<P STYLE="text-align: left"><B><FONT style="FONT-VARIANT: small-caps" face="Times New Roman" size=2>Code of Ethics</FONT></B></P>



<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=3>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; </FONT>The Board of
Directors has adopted </FONT><I><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>The Kroger
Co. Policy on Business Ethics</FONT></I><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>,
applicable to all officers, employees and members of the Board of Directors,
including Kroger&#146;s principal executive, financial, and accounting officers. The
</FONT><I><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Policy</FONT></I><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2> is available on our corporate website at
ir.kroger.com. Shareholders may obtain a copy of the </FONT><I><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Policy</FONT></I><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2> by making a written request to Kroger&#146;s Secretary at our executive
offices. We intend to satisfy the disclosure requirement regarding any amendment
to, or a waiver from, a provision of the </FONT><I><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Policy</FONT></I><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2> for our principal
executive, financial and accounting officers by posting that information on our
website at ir.kroger.com.</FONT></P>
<P align=center><B><FONT face="Times New Roman">16</FONT></B></P>
<HR align=center width="100%" noShade SIZE=2>


<DIV style="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: always"></DIV><BR>


<P align=left><FONT style="FONT-VARIANT: small-caps" size=2><STRONG>Communications with the Board</STRONG></FONT></P>
<P align=justify>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>The Board has
established two separate mechanisms for shareholders and interested parties to
communicate with the Board. Any shareholder or interested party who has concerns
regarding accounting, improper use of Kroger assets, or ethical improprieties
may report these concerns via the toll-free hotline (800-689-4609) or email
address (helpline@kroger.com) established by the Board&#146;s Audit Committee. The
concerns are investigated by Kroger&#146;s Vice President of Auditing and reported to
the Audit Committee as deemed appropriate by the Vice President of
Auditing.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>Shareholders or interested parties also may communicate with the Board in
writing directed to Kroger&#146;s Secretary at our executive offices. The Secretary
will consider the nature of the communication and determine whether to forward
the communication to the chair of the Corporate Governance Committee.
Communications relating to personnel issues or our ordinary business operations,
or seeking to do business with us, will be forwarded to the business unit of
Kroger that the Secretary deems appropriate. All other communications will be
forwarded to the chair of the Corporate Governance Committee for further
consideration. The chair of the Corporate Governance Committee will take such
action as he or she deems appropriate, which may include referral to the
Corporate Governance Committee or the entire Board.</FONT></P>
<P align=left><FONT style="FONT-VARIANT: small-caps" size=2><STRONG>Attendance</STRONG></FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>The Board of Directors held seven meetings in 2013. During 2013, all
incumbent directors attended at least 75% of the aggregate number of meetings of
the Board and committees on which that director served. Members of the Board are
expected to use their best efforts to attend all annual meetings of
shareholders. All fourteen</FONT><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2> </FONT></B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>members then serving on the Board attended last year&#146;s annual
meeting.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT style="FONT-VARIANT: small-caps" size=2><STRONG>Compensation Consultants</STRONG></FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>The Compensation Committee directly engages a compensation consultant
from Mercer Human Resource Consulting to advise the Committee in the design of
compensation for executive officers. In 2013, Kroger paid that consultant
$375,944 for work performed for the Committee. Kroger, on management&#146;s
recommendation, retained the parent and affiliated companies of Mercer Human
Resource Consulting to provide other services for Kroger in 2013, for which
Kroger paid $4,743,100. These other services primarily related to insurance
claims (for which Kroger was reimbursed by insurance carriers as claims were
adjusted), insurance brokerage and bonding commissions, and pension consulting.
Kroger also made payments to affiliated companies for insurance premiums that
were collected by the affiliated companies on behalf of insurance carriers, but
these amounts are not included in the totals referenced above, as the amounts
were paid over to insurance carriers for services provided by those carriers.
Although neither the Committee nor the Board expressly approved the other
services, after taking into consideration the NYSE&#146;s independence standards and
the SEC rules, the Committee determined that the consultant is independent and
his work has not raised any conflict of interest because (a) he was first
engaged by the Committee before he became associated with Mercer; (b) he works
exclusively for the Committee and not for our management; (c) he does not
benefit from the other work that Mercer&#146;s parent and affiliated companies
perform for Kroger; and (d) neither the consultant nor the consultant&#146;s team
perform any other services on behalf of Kroger.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>No member of the Compensation Committee was an officer or employee of the
Company during fiscal year 2013, and no member of the Compensation Committee was
formerly an officer of the Company or was a party to any disclosable related
person transaction involving the Company. During fiscal year 2013, none of the
executive officers of the Company served on the board of directors or on the
compensation committee of any other entity that has or had executive officers
serving as a member of the Board of Directors or Compensation Committee of the
Company.</FONT></P>
<P align=center><B><FONT face="Times New Roman">17</FONT></B></P>
<HR align=center width="100%" noShade SIZE=2>

<DIV style="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: always"></DIV><BR>
<P align=left><FONT style="FONT-VARIANT: small-caps" size=2><B>Board Oversight
of Enterprise Risk</B></FONT></P>
<P align=justify>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>While risk
management is primarily the responsibility of Kroger&#146;s management team, the
Board of Directors is responsible for the overall supervision of our risk
management activities. The Board&#146;s oversight of the material risks faced by
Kroger occurs at both the full Board level and at the committee level.
</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>The Board&#146;s Audit Committee has oversight responsibility not only for
financial reporting of Kroger&#146;s major financial exposures and the steps
management has taken to monitor and control those exposures, but also for the
effectiveness of management&#146;s processes that monitor and manage key business
risks facing Kroger, as well as the major areas of risk exposure and
management&#146;s efforts to monitor and control that exposure. The Audit Committee
also discusses with management its policies with respect to risk assessment and
risk management.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>Management, including Kroger&#146;s Chief Ethics and Compliance Officer,
provides regular updates throughout the year to the respective committees
regarding the management of the risks they oversee, and each of these committees
reports on risk to the full Board at each regular meeting of the
Board.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>In addition to the reports from the committees, the Board receives
presentations throughout the year from various department and business unit
leaders that include discussion of significant risks as necessary. At each Board
meeting, the Chairman and the CEO address matters of particular importance or
concern, including any significant areas of risk that require Board attention.
Additionally, through dedicated sessions focusing entirely on corporate
strategy, the full Board reviews in detail Kroger&#146;s short- and long-term
strategies, including consideration of significant risks facing Kroger and their
potential impact. The independent directors, in executive sessions led by the
Lead Director, address matters of particular concern, including significant
areas of risk, that warrant further discussion or consideration outside the
presence of Kroger employees.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>We believe that our approach to risk oversight, as described above,
optimizes our ability to assess inter-relationships among the various risks,
make informed cost-benefit decisions, and approach emerging risks in a proactive
manner for Kroger. We also believe that our risk structure complements our
current Board leadership structure, as it allows our independent directors,
through the five fully independent Board committees, and in executive sessions
of independent directors led by an independent Lead Director, to exercise
effective oversight of the actions of management, led by Mr. McMullen as CEO, in
identifying risks and implementing effective risk management policies and
controls.</FONT></P>
<P align=left><FONT style="FONT-VARIANT: small-caps" size=2><B>Board Leadership
Structure and Lead Director</B></FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>Our Board is composed of eleven independent non-employee directors, and
two management directors, Mr. Dillon, the Chairman of the Board and our former
Chief Executive Officer, and Mr. McMullen, our Chief Executive Officer. In
addition, as provided in our </FONT><I><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Guidelines on
Issues of Corporate Governance</FONT></I><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>, the Board has
designated one of the independent directors as Lead Director. The Board has
established five standing committees &#151; audit, compensation, corporate
governance, financial policy, and public responsibilities. Each Board committee
is composed solely of independent directors, each with a different independent
director serving as committee chair. The mix of experienced independent and
management directors that make up our Board, along with the independent role of
our Lead Director and our independent Board committees, benefits Kroger and its
shareholders.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>The Board designates one of the independent directors as a Lead Director.
The Lead Director serves a variety of roles, including reviewing and approving
Board agendas, meeting materials and schedules to confirm the appropriate topics
are reviewed and sufficient time is allocated to each; serving as liaison
between the Chairman of the Board, management, and the non-management directors;
presiding at the executive sessions of independent directors and at all other
meetings of the Board of Directors at which the Chairman of the Board is not
present; calling an executive session of independent directors at any time and
serving as the Board&#146;s representative for any consultation and direct
communication, following a request, with major shareholders. Unless otherwise
determined by the Board, the chair of the Corporate Governance Committee is
designated as the Lead Director. Robert Beyer, an independent director and the
chair of the Corporate Governance Committee, is currently our Lead Director. Mr.
Beyer is an effective Lead Director for Kroger due to, among other things, his
independence, his deep strategic and operational understanding of Kroger
obtained while serving as a Kroger director, his insight into corporate
governance and his experience on other boards.</FONT></P>
<P align=center><B><FONT face="Times New Roman">18</FONT></B></P>
<HR align=center width="100%" noShade SIZE=2>

<DIV style="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: always"></DIV><BR>
<P align=justify>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>With respect
to the roles of Chairman and CEO, the </FONT><I><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Guidelines</FONT></I><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2> provide that the Board will
determine when it is in the best interests of Kroger and its shareholders for
the roles to be separated or combined, and the Board exercises its discretion as
it deems appropriate in light of prevailing circumstances. As part of the
succession planning process, the </FONT><I><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Guidelines</FONT></I><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2> provide that upon the
selection of a new Chief Executive Officer, the Board will determine whether a
separation of the offices is appropriate. The Board believes that the
combination or separation of these positions should continue to be considered as
part of the succession planning process, as was the case in 2003, and again in
2014, when the roles were separated. </FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>Our Board and each of its committees conduct an annual evaluation to
determine whether they are functioning effectively. As part of this annual
self-evaluation, the Board assesses whether the current leadership structure
continues to be appropriate for Kroger and its shareholders. Our </FONT><I><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Guidelines</FONT></I><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2> provide the
flexibility for our Board to modify our leadership structure in the future as
appropriate. We believe that Kroger, like many U.S. companies, has been
well-served by this flexible leadership structure.</FONT></P>
<P align=center><B><FONT face="Times New Roman">19</FONT></B></P>
<HR align=center width="100%" noShade SIZE=2>

<DIV style="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: always"></DIV><BR>
<TABLE style="LINE-HEIGHT: 14pt; BORDER-COLLAPSE: collapse" cellSpacing=0 cellPadding=0 width="100%" border=0>

  <TR vAlign=bottom>
    <TD style="BORDER-BOTTOM: #000000 1pt solid" noWrap align=center width="100%"><FONT style="FONT-VARIANT: small-caps" size=2><B>Compensation Discussion and
Analysis</B></FONT></TD></TR></TABLE><BR>
<P align=left><FONT style="FONT-VARIANT: small-caps" size=2><B>Executive
Compensation &#150; Overview</B></FONT></P>
<P align=justify>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>As one of the
largest retailers in the world, our executive compensation philosophy remains to
attract and retain the best management talent and to motivate these employees to
achieve our business and financial goals. We believe our strategy creates value
for shareholders in a manner consistent with our focus on our core values:
honesty, integrity, respect, inclusion, diversity, and safety.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>To achieve our objectives, our Compensation Committee seeks to ensure
that compensation is competitive and that there is a direct link between pay and
performance. To do so, it is guided by the following principles:</FONT></P>
<UL style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; text-align: justify"><LI><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>A significant portion of pay should be
  performance-based, increasing proportionally with an executive&#146;s</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>level of responsibility;</FONT> <BR>&nbsp;
  </LI><LI><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Compensation should include incentive-based pay to
  drive performance, providing superior pay for</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>superior performance, including both a short- and long-term
  focus;</FONT> <BR>&nbsp;
  </LI><LI><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Compensation policies should include an
  opportunity for, and a requirement of, equity ownership; and</FONT> <BR>&nbsp;

  </LI><LI><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Components of compensation should be tied to an
  evaluation of business and individual performance</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>measured against metrics that align with our business strategy.</FONT>
  </LI></UL>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>The compensation of our senior executives in fiscal year 2013 reflects
these principles. Total compensation for the year is an indicator of how well
Kroger performed compared to our business plan, reflecting how our compensation
program responds to business challenges and the marketplace. We continue to
deliver sales growth and positive earnings results.</FONT></P>
<UL style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; text-align: justify"><LI><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>A key metric, identical supermarket sales,
  excluding the 53<SUP>rd </SUP>week in 2012 and fuel, increased 3.6%
  from</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>2012. Through fiscal 2013, we have
  achieved 41 consecutive quarters of positive identical sales growth.</FONT>
  <BR>&nbsp;
  </LI><LI><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Net earnings per diluted share were $2.90, and
  even after taking into account several items that we</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>believe are necessary to make these results comparable to fiscal 2012,
  our results still exceeded our</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>guidance
  range.</FONT> <BR>&nbsp;
  </LI><LI><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>In September 2013, the Board of Directors raised
  the quarterly cash dividend by 10%, to $0.165 per share.</FONT> <BR>&nbsp;
  </LI><LI><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Kroger&#146;s stock price increased 29.4% in fiscal
  year 2013.</FONT> </LI></UL>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>The Committee believes our management produced outstanding results in
2013, measured against increasingly aggressive business plan objectives for
sales, earnings, and our strategic plan. The compensation paid to our named
executive officers reflected this fact as the annual performance-based cash
bonus paid out at 104.949% of bonus potentials. The strong link between pay and
performance is illustrated by a comparison of the 2012 annual cash bonus, with
an 85.881% payout. In 2012, we performed well but did not achieve all of our
business plan objectives. In 2013, all of our business plan goals were exceeded
(with the exception of our sales goal, which fell slightly short), resulting in
an annual bonus payout that exceeded 100% of potentials.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>In keeping with our overall compensation philosophy, we endeavor to
ensure that our compensation practices conform to best practices. In particular,
over the past several years we have:</FONT></P>
<UL style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; text-align: justify"><LI><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>put in place significant stock ownership guideline
  levels to reinforce the link between the interests of</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>our named executive officers and those of our shareholders;</FONT>
  <BR>&nbsp;
  </LI><LI><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>adopted claw-back policies under which the
  repayment of bonuses may be required in</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>certain
  circumstances;</FONT> <BR>&nbsp;
  </LI><LI><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>eliminated tax gross-ups;</FONT> <BR>&nbsp;
  </LI><LI><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>adopted the recommendation of shareholders that
  they be permitted annually, on an advisory basis, to</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>vote on executive compensation; and</FONT> <BR>&nbsp;
  </LI><LI><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>adopted a policy prohibiting hedging and short
  sales, and restricting pledging, of Kroger common shares</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>by our officers and directors.</FONT> </LI></UL>
<P align=center><B><FONT face="Times New Roman">20</FONT></B></P>
<HR align=center width="100%" noShade SIZE=2>

<DIV style="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: always"></DIV><BR>
<P align=justify>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>In addition,
beginning in 2010, fifty percent of the time-based equity awards that otherwise
would have been granted to the named executive officers as restricted stock have
been replaced with performance units that are earned only to the extent that
performance objectives are achieved. Equity compensation awards continue to play
an important role in rewarding named executive officers for the achievement of
long-term business objectives and providing incentives for the creation of
shareholder value. </FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>The following discussion and analysis addresses the compensation of the
named executive officers, and the factors considered by the Committee in setting
compensation for the named executive officers and making recommendations to the
independent Board members in the case of the CEO&#146;s compensation. Additional
detail is provided in the compensation tables and the accompanying narrative
disclosures that follow this discussion and analysis.</FONT></P>
<P align=left><FONT style="FONT-VARIANT: small-caps" size=2><B>Executive
Compensation &#150; Objectives</B></FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>The Committee has several related objectives regarding compensation.
First, the Committee believes that compensation must be designed to attract and
retain those best suited to fulfill the challenging roles that executive
officers play at Kroger. Second, some elements of compensation should help align
the interests of the officers with your interests as shareholders. Third,
compensation should create strong incentives for the officers (a) to achieve the
annual business plan targets established by the Board, and (b) to achieve
Kroger&#146;s long-term strategic objectives. In developing compensation programs and
amounts to meet these objectives, the Committee exercises judgment to ensure
that executive officer compensation is appropriate and competitive in light of
Kroger&#146;s performance and the needs of the business.</FONT></P>
<P align=left><FONT style="FONT-VARIANT: small-caps" size=2><B>Share Ownership
Guidelines</B></FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>To more closely align the interests of the officers with your interests
as shareholders, the Board of Directors has adopted stock ownership guidelines.
These guidelines require non-employee directors, officers and some other key
executives to acquire and hold a minimum dollar value of Kroger common shares.
The guidelines require the CEO to acquire and maintain ownership of Kroger
shares equal to five times his base salary; the Chief Operating Officer at four
times his base salary; Executive Vice Presidents, Senior Vice Presidents and
non-employee directors at three times their base salaries or annual base cash
retainers; and other officers and key executives at two times their base
salaries. Covered individuals are expected to achieve the target level within
five years of appointment to their position. Kroger shares, including equity
awards from Kroger, may not be sold by covered individuals prior to achieving
holdings required by the guidelines (other than to pay for the exercise price of
options and the taxes associated with equity awards), without the approval of
Kroger&#146;s CEO.</FONT></P>
<P align=left><FONT style="FONT-VARIANT: small-caps" size=2><B>Results of 2013
Advisory Vote to Approve Executive Compensation</B></FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>At the 2013 Annual Meeting of Shareholders, we held our third annual
advisory vote on executive compensation. Over 97% of the votes cast were in
favor of the advisory proposal in 2013. The Committee considered this
overwhelmingly favorable outcome and believes it conveys our shareholders&#146;
support of the Committee&#146;s decisions and the existing executive compensation
programs. As a result, the Committee made no material changes in the structure
of our compensation programs or pay for performance philosophy. At the 2014
Annual Meeting of Shareholders, in keeping with our shareholders&#146; request for an
annual advisory vote, we will again hold a vote to approve executive
compensation (see page 55). The Committee will continue to consider the results
from this year&#146;s and future advisory votes on executive compensation.</FONT></P>
<P align=left><FONT style="FONT-VARIANT: small-caps" size=2><B>Role of
Compensation Committee</B></FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>The Compensation Committee of the Board has the primary responsibility
for establishing the compensation of Kroger&#146;s executive officers, including the
named executive officers, with the exception of the Chief Executive Officer. The
Committee&#146;s role regarding the CEO&#146;s compensation is to make recommendations to
the independent members of the Board; those independent Board members establish
the CEO&#146;s compensation.</FONT></P>
<P align=center><B><FONT face="Times New Roman">21</FONT></B></P>
<HR align=center width="100%" noShade SIZE=2>

<DIV style="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: always"></DIV><BR>
<P align=left><FONT style="FONT-VARIANT: small-caps" size=2><B>Establishing
Executive Compensation</B></FONT></P>
<P align=justify>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>The
independent members of the Board have the exclusive authority to determine the
amount of the CEO&#146;s salary; the bonus potential for the CEO; the nature and
amount of any equity awards made to the CEO; and any other compensation
questions related to the CEO. In setting the annual bonus potential for the CEO,
the independent directors determine the dollar amount that will be multiplied by
the percentage payout under the annual bonus plan generally applicable to all
corporate management, including the named executive officers. The independent
directors retain discretion to reduce the percentage payout the CEO would
otherwise receive. The independent directors thus make a separate determination
annually concerning both the CEO&#146;s bonus potential and the percentage of bonus
paid.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>The Committee performs the same function and exercises the same authority
as to the other named executive officers. The Committee&#146;s annual review of
compensation for the named executive officers includes the following:</FONT></P>
<UL style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; text-align: justify"><LI><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Conducts an annual review of all components of
  compensation, quantifying total compensation for the</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>named executive officers on tally sheets. The review includes a summary
  for each named executive officer</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>of salary;
  annual performance-based cash bonus; long-term performance-based cash and
  performance</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>unit compensation; equity;
  accumulated realized and unrealized stock option gains and restricted
  stock</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>and performance unit values; the value of
  any perquisites; retirement benefits; severance benefits</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>available under The Kroger Co. Employee Protection Plan; and
  earnings and payouts available under</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Kroger&#146;s
  nonqualified deferred compensation program.</FONT> <BR>&nbsp;
  </LI><LI><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Considers internal pay equity at Kroger to ensure
  that the CEO is not compensated disproportionately.</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>The Committee has assured itself that the compensation of Kroger&#146;s CEO
  and that of the other named</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>executive officers
  bears a reasonable relationship to the compensation levels of other executive
  positions</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>at Kroger taking into consideration
  performance and differences in responsibilities.</FONT> <BR>&nbsp;
  </LI><LI><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Reviews a report from the Committee&#146;s compensation
  consultants (described below) comparing named</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>executive officer and other senior executive compensation with that of
  other companies, primarily our</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>competitors, to
  ensure that the Committee&#146;s objectives of competitiveness are met.</FONT>
<BR>&nbsp;
  </LI><LI><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Takes into account a recommendation from the CEO
  (except in the case of his own compensation) for</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>salary, bonus potential, and equity awards for each of the senior
  officers including the other named</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>executive
  officers. The CEO&#146;s recommendation takes into consideration the objectives
  established by</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>and the reports received by the
  Committee as well as his assessment of individual job performance and</FONT>
  <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>contribution to our management team.</FONT> <BR>&nbsp;
  </LI><LI><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Looks at historical information regarding salary,
  bonus, and equity compensation for a 3-year period.</FONT> </LI></UL>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>In considering each of the factors above, the Committee does not make use
of a formula, but rather subjectively reviews each in setting
compensation.</FONT></P>
<P align=left><FONT style="FONT-VARIANT: small-caps" size=2><B>The Committee&#146;s
Compensation Consultants and Benchmarking</B></FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>As referenced earlier in this compensation discussion and analysis, the
Committee directly engages a compensation consultant from Mercer Human Resource
Consulting to advise the Committee in the design of compensation for executive
officers.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>The Mercer consultant conducts an annual competitive assessment of
executive positions at Kroger for the Committee. The assessment is one of
several bases, as described above, on which the Committee determines
compensation. The consultant assesses:</FONT></P>
<UL style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; text-align: justify"><LI><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Base salary;</FONT> <BR>&nbsp;
  </LI><LI><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Target annual performance-based bonus;</FONT>
<BR>&nbsp;
  </LI><LI><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Target annual cash compensation (the sum of salary
  and annual bonus);</FONT> <BR>&nbsp;
  </LI><LI><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Annualized long-term incentive awards, such as
  stock options, restricted shares, and performance-based</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>long-term cash bonuses and performance-based equity awards;
  and</FONT> <BR>&nbsp;
  </LI><LI><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Total direct compensation (the sum of all these
  elements).</FONT> </LI></UL>
<P align=center><B><FONT face="Times New Roman">22</FONT></B></P>
<HR align=center width="100%" noShade SIZE=2>

<DIV style="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: always"></DIV><BR>
<P align=justify>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>The consultant
compares these elements against those of other companies in a group of
publicly-traded food and drug retailers. For 2013, the group consisted of:
</FONT></P>
<DIV align=center>
<TABLE style="LINE-HEIGHT: 14pt; BORDER-COLLAPSE: collapse" cellSpacing=0 cellPadding=0 width="80%" border=0>

  <TR vAlign=bottom>
    <TD noWrap align=left width="49%"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Costco Wholesale</FONT></TD>
    <TD noWrap align=left width="50%"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Supervalu</FONT></TD></TR>
  <TR vAlign=bottom>
    <TD noWrap align=left width="49%"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>CVS/Caremark</FONT></TD>
    <TD noWrap align=left width="50%"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Target</FONT></TD></TR>
  <TR vAlign=bottom>
    <TD noWrap align=left width="49%"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Rite Aid</FONT></TD>
    <TD noWrap align=left width="50%"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Wal-Mart</FONT></TD></TR>
  <TR vAlign=bottom>
    <TD noWrap align=left width="49%"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Safeway</FONT></TD>
    <TD noWrap align=left width="50%"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Walgreens</FONT></TD></TR></TABLE></DIV><BR>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>This peer group is the same group as was used in 2012. The make-up of the
compensation peer group is reviewed annually and modified as circumstances
warrant. Industry consolidation and other competitive forces will change the
peer group used over time. The consultant also provides the Committee data from
companies in &#147;general industry,&#148; a representation of major publicly-traded
companies. These data are reference points, particularly for senior staff
positions where competition for talent extends beyond the retail
sector.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>In 2009, the Committee directly engaged an additional compensation
consultant to conduct a review of Kroger&#146;s executive compensation. This
consultant, from Frederic W. Cook &amp; Co., Inc., examined the compensation
philosophy, peer group composition, annual cash bonus, and long-term incentive
compensation including equity awards. The consultant concluded that Kroger&#146;s
executive compensation program met the Committee&#146;s objectives, and that it
provides a strong linkage between pay and performance. The Committee expects to
engage an additional compensation consultant from time to time as it deems
advisable.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>Considering the size of Kroger in relation to other peer group companies,
the Committee believes that salaries paid to our executive officers should be at
or above the median paid by competitors for comparable positions. The committee
also aims to provide an annual bonus potential to our executive officers that,
if the increasingly more challenging annual business plan objectives are
achieved, would cause total cash compensation to be meaningfully above the
median.</FONT></P>
<P align=left><FONT style="FONT-VARIANT: small-caps" size=2><B>Components of
Executive Compensation at Kroger</B></FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>Compensation for our named executive officers is comprised of the
following:</FONT></P>
<UL style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; text-align: justify"><LI STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Salary;</FONT> <BR>&nbsp;
  </LI><LI STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Performance-Based Annual Cash Bonus (annual,
  non-equity incentive pay);</FONT> <BR>&nbsp;
  </LI><LI STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Performance-Based Long-Term Compensation
  (long-term, cash and performance unit</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>incentive
  compensation);</FONT> <BR>&nbsp;
  </LI><LI STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Other Equity (non-qualified stock options and
  restricted stock);</FONT> <BR>&nbsp;
  </LI><LI STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Retirement and other benefits; and</FONT>
  <BR>&nbsp;
  </LI><LI STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Perquisites.</FONT> </LI></UL>
<P align=left><FONT style="FONT-VARIANT: small-caps" size=2><B>Salary</B></FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>We provide our named executive officers and other employees a fixed
amount of cash compensation &#150; salary &#150; for their work. Salaries for named
executive officers (with the exception of the CEO) are established each year by
the Committee, in consultation with the CEO. The CEO&#146;s salary is established by
the independent directors. Salaries for the named executive officers were
reviewed in June 2013.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>The amount of each executive&#146;s salary is influenced by numerous factors
including:</FONT></P>
<UL style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; text-align: justify"><LI><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>An assessment of individual contribution in the
  judgment of the CEO and the Committee (or, in the case</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>of the CEO, of the Committee and the rest of the independent
  directors);</FONT> <BR>&nbsp;
  </LI><LI><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Benchmarking with comparable positions at peer
  group companies;</FONT> <BR>&nbsp;
  </LI><LI><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Tenure; and</FONT> <BR>&nbsp;
  </LI><LI><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Relationship with the salaries of other executives
  at Kroger.</FONT> </LI></UL>
<P align=center><B><FONT face="Times New Roman">23</FONT></B></P>
<HR align=center width="100%" noShade SIZE=2>

<DIV style="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: always"></DIV><BR>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>The assessment of individual contribution is based on a subjective
determination, without the use of performance targets, in the following
areas:</FONT></P>
<UL style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; text-align: justify"><LI><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Leadership;</FONT> <BR>&nbsp;
  </LI><LI><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Contribution to the officer group;</FONT>
  <BR>&nbsp;
  </LI><LI><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Achievement of established objectives, to the
  extent applicable;</FONT> <BR>&nbsp;
  </LI><LI><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Decision-making abilities;</FONT> <BR>&nbsp;
  </LI><LI><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Performance of the areas or groups directly
  reporting to the officer;</FONT> <BR>&nbsp;
  </LI><LI><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Increased responsibilities;</FONT> <BR>&nbsp;
  </LI><LI><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Strategic thinking; and</FONT> <BR>&nbsp;
  </LI><LI><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Furtherance of Kroger&#146;s core values.</FONT>
</LI></UL>
<P align=justify>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>The amounts
shown below reflect the salaries of the named executive officers in effect
following the annual review of their compensation in June.</FONT></P>

<P align=left><FONT style="FONT-VARIANT: small-caps" size=2><B>Performance-Based
Annual Cash Bonus</B></FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>A large percentage of our employees at all levels, including the named
executive officers, are eligible to receive a performance-based annual cash
bonus based on the performance of Kroger (in the case of the named executive
officers) or business unit (in the case of employees in our business units). The
Committee establishes bonus potentials for each executive officer, other than
the CEO whose bonus potential is established by the independent directors.
Actual payouts, which can exceed 100% of the potential amounts but may not
exceed 200% of the potential amounts, represent the extent to which performance
meets or exceeds the thresholds established by the Committee.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>The Committee considers several factors in making its determination or
recommendation as to bonus potentials. First, the individual&#146;s level within the
organization is a factor in that the Committee believes that more senior
executives should have a substantial part of their compensation dependent upon
Kroger&#146;s performance. Second, the individual&#146;s salary is a factor so that a
substantial portion of a named executive officer&#146;s total cash compensation is
dependent upon Kroger&#146;s performance. Finally, the Committee considers the
reports of its compensation consultants to assess the bonus potential of the
named executive officers in light of total compensation paid to comparable
executive positions in the industry.</FONT></P>
<P align=center><B><FONT face="Times New Roman">24</FONT></B></P>
<HR align=center width="100%" noShade SIZE=2>

<DIV style="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: always"></DIV><BR>

June for each named executive officer is shown below. Actual bonus payouts are
prorated to reflect changes, if any, to bonus potentials during the
year.</FONT></P>

      $750,000 effective with his promotion to President and COO on January 1,

<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>Over time the Committee and our independent directors have placed an
increased emphasis on our strategic plan by making the target more difficult to
achieve. The bonus plan allows for minimal bonus to be earned at relatively low
levels of performance to provide incentive for achieving even higher levels of
performance.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>The amount of bonus that the named executive officers earn each year is
determined by Kroger&#146;s performance compared to targets established by the
Committee and our independent directors based on the business plan adopted by
the Board of Directors. In 2013, one-third of the bonus was based on a target
for identical sales without fuel; one-third was based on a target for EBITDA
without fuel; and one-third was based on implementation and results of a set of
measures under our strategic plan. An additional 5% would be earned if Kroger
achieved three goals with respect to its supermarket fuel operations:
achievement of the targeted fuel EBITDA, increase of at least 3% in total
gallons sold,</FONT><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2> </FONT></B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>and achievement of the planned number of fuel centers placed in
service.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>Following the close of the year, the Committee reviewed Kroger&#146;s
performance against the identical sales without fuel, EBITDA without fuel, and
strategic plan objectives and determined the extent to which Kroger achieved
those objectives.</FONT><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2> </FONT></B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Kroger&#146;s EBITDA without fuel for 2013 was $4.245 billion and Kroger&#146;s
identical sales without fuel for 2013 were 3.5%. In 2013, Kroger&#146;s supermarket
fuel EBITDA was $232.990 million, which exceeded the goal of $184.875 million
necessary to earn a bonus for the fuel component. Kroger&#146;s fuel gallon sales in
supermarket fuel centers were 4.431 billion gallons, or 6.6% over the prior
year. We operated 1,240 supermarket fuel centers as of the end of 2013,
exceeding our goal of 1,235 centers. As a result, the payout percentage included
the additional 5% fuel bonus. Due to our performance when compared to the
targets established by the Committee, and based on the business plan adopted by
the Board of Directors, the named executive officers earned 104.949% of their
bonus potentials. This is the same bonus percentage payout received by all other
participants in the annual corporate bonus plan. </FONT></P>
<P align=center><B><FONT face="Times New Roman">25</FONT></B></P>
<HR align=center width="100%" noShade SIZE=2>

    <TD noWrap align=left width="1%"></TD>
    <TD noWrap align=left width="1%"></TD>
    <TD style="BORDER-BOTTOM: #000000 1pt solid" noWrap align=right width="3%"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>5.000</FONT></TD>
    <TD style="BORDER-BOTTOM: #000000 1pt solid" noWrap align=left width="1%"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>%</FONT></TD>
    <TD noWrap align=left width="1%"></TD></TR>
  <TR vAlign=bottom>
    <TD noWrap align=left width="79%" bgColor=#c0c0c0 colSpan=2><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Total Earned</FONT></TD>
    <TD noWrap align=left width="3%" bgColor=#c0c0c0></TD>
    <TD noWrap align=left width="3%" bgColor=#c0c0c0></TD>
    <TD noWrap align=left width="1%" bgColor=#c0c0c0>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD noWrap align=left width="3%" bgColor=#c0c0c0></TD>
    <TD noWrap align=left width="1%" bgColor=#c0c0c0></TD>
    <TD noWrap align=left width="3%" bgColor=#c0c0c0></TD>
    <TD noWrap align=left width="1%" bgColor=#c0c0c0></TD>
    <TD noWrap align=left width="1%" bgColor=#c0c0c0></TD>
    <TD style="BORDER-BOTTOM: #000000 1pt solid" noWrap align=right width="3%" bgColor=#c0c0c0><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>104.949</FONT></TD>
    <TD style="BORDER-BOTTOM: #000000 1pt solid" noWrap align=left width="1%" bgColor=#c0c0c0><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>%</FONT></TD>
    <TD noWrap align=left width="1%" bgColor=#c0c0c0></TD></TR></TABLE>____________________<BR>&nbsp;
<TABLE style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify" cellSpacing=0 cellPadding=0 border=0>

  <TR>
    <TD vAlign=top noWrap><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>*</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="100%"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Payout is at 125% if identical
      sales goal is achieved.</FONT></TD></TR>
  <TR>
    <TD colSpan=2><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD></TR>
  <TR>
    <TD vAlign=top noWrap><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>**&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="100%"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>The Strategic Plan component also
      was established by the Committee, but is not disclosed as it is
      competitively sensitive.</FONT></TD></TR></TABLE>
<P align=justify>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>In 2013,
as in all years, the Committee retained discretion to reduce the bonus payout
for all executive officers, including the named executive officers, if the
Committee determined for any reason that the bonus payouts were not appropriate.
The independent directors retained that discretion for the CEO&#146;s bonus. Those
bodies also retained discretion to adjust the targets under the plan should
unanticipated developments arise during the year. No adjustments were made to
the targets in 2013. The Committee, and the independent directors in the case of
the CEO, determined that the bonus payouts for the named executive officers
should remain the same as other participants.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT>The percentage paid for 2013
represented excellent performance that exceeded our business plan objectives. A
comparison of bonus percentages for the named executive officers in prior years
demonstrates the variability of annual cash bonus incentive
compensation:</FONT></P>
<DIV align=center>

    <TD noWrap align=left width="1%"></TD></TR></TABLE></DIV><BR>
<P align=justify>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>The
actual amounts of annual performance-based cash bonuses paid to the named
executive officers for 2013 are reported in the Summary Compensation Table under
the heading &#147;Non-Equity Incentive Plan Compensation&#148; and footnote 4. These
amounts represent the bonus potentials for each named executive officer
multiplied by the 104.949% payout percentage earned in 2013. In no event can any
participant receive a performance-based annual cash bonus in excess of
$5,000,000. The maximum amount that a participant, including each named
executive officer, can earn is further limited to 200% of the participant&#146;s
bonus potential amount.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT>The performance-based annual cash
bonus for 2014 will be determined based on Kroger&#146;s performance against the
identical sales without fuel, EBITDA without fuel, strategic plan, and operating
costs as a percentage of sales objectives established by the Committee. The
first three metrics will be weighted at 30% each and the final metric will be
weighted at 10%. The underlying strategy metrics have been revised from prior
years to focus on shorter-term measures, as the long-term bonus emphasizes
long-term performance. The 2014 plan also provides for an additional 5% payout
if our goals for supermarket fuel EBITDA, supermarket fuel gallons sold, and
targeted number of fuel centers in operation at the fiscal year end are
achieved.</FONT></P>
<P align=center><B><FONT face="Times New Roman">26</FONT></B></P>

<HR align=center width="100%" noShade SIZE=2>


<DIV style="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: always"></DIV><BR>
<P align=justify><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT style="FONT-VARIANT: small-caps" size=2>Long-Term
Incentives</FONT></FONT></B><B></B></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT>The Committee believes in the
importance of providing an incentive to the named executive officers to achieve
the long-term goals established by the Board of Directors by conditioning a
significant portion of compensation on the achievement of those goals.
</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT>In 2006, the Committee adopted the
first in a series of long-term performance based compensation plans designed to
reward participants for their contribution to the long-term performance of
Kroger. These earlier plans provided for overlapping four year performance
periods that allowed for the earning of a long-term cash bonus. In 2010,
Kroger&#146;s long-term incentive program was redesigned to combine the total value
of our long-term cash bonus and equity programs into a cohesive, strategic
reward for eligible executives at the Vice President level and above.
Approximately fifty percent of the plan value is performance-based, delivered in
cash and performance units, contingent on the achievement of certain strategic
performance measures. The other fifty percent of the value is time-based and
delivered in stock options and restricted shares. Each component is described in
more detail below. </FONT></P>
<P align=justify><B><FONT style="FONT-VARIANT: small-caps" face="Times New Roman" size=2>Performance Based Long-Term Compensation</FONT></B></P>
<P align=justify>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>The
long-term incentive plan adopted in 2010 (and earned in 2012) provides the model
for our combined plan structure. Subsequent plans have been adopted each year
thereafter. Each of these plans has the following characteristics:</FONT></P>
<UL><LI>
  <P STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Performance is measured over a three
  year period.</FONT></P>
  </LI><LI>
  <P STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Between 130 and 170 executives,
  including the named executive officers, participate in each plan. </FONT></P>
  </LI><LI>
  <P STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Awards include both cash and
  performance units. </FONT></P></LI></UL>
<TABLE style="LINE-HEIGHT: normal; BORDER-COLLAPSE: collapse" cellSpacing=0 cellPadding=0 width="100%" border=0>

  <TR vAlign=bottom>
    <TD style="PADDING-LEFT: 30pt" vAlign=top align=left width="1%"><FONT face=Wingdings size=2>&#216;</FONT></TD>
    <TD vAlign=top align=left width="1%"><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT" WIDTH="97%" STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>The cash bonus base equals the
      executive&#146;s salary at the end of the fiscal year preceding the plan
      adoption date (or for those participants entering the plan after the
      commencement date, as of the date of commencing participation in the
      plan).</FONT></TD></TR>
  <TR>
    <TD vAlign=top width="1%"></TD>
    <TD vAlign=top width="1%"></TD>
    <TD vAlign=top width="97%">&nbsp;</TD></TR>
  <TR vAlign=bottom>
    <TD style="PADDING-LEFT: 30pt" vAlign=top align=left width="1%"><FONT face=Wingdings size=2>&#216;</FONT></TD>
    <TD vAlign=top align=left width="1%"></TD>
    <TD VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT" WIDTH="97%" STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>A fixed number of performance units
      is awarded to each participant. The awards are paid out in Kroger common
      shares, along with a cash amount equal to the dividends paid during the
      performance period on the number of issued common
  shares.</FONT></TD></TR></TABLE><BR>
<UL><LI>
  <P STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Compensation under the plans is
  earned based on our performance against metrics established by the Committee
  at the beginning of the performance period. </FONT></P>
  </LI><LI>
  <P STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>The payout percentage, based on the
  extent to which the performance metrics are achieved, is applied to both the
  bonus base and the number of performance units awarded. </FONT></P>
  </LI><LI>
  <P STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Actual payouts cannot exceed 100% of
  the cash bonus base or 100% of the number of performance units
  awarded.</FONT></P>
  </LI><LI>
  <P STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>In no event can a cash bonus award
  exceed $5,000,000.</FONT></P></LI></UL>
<P align=center><B><FONT face="Times New Roman">27</FONT></B></P>
<HR align=center width="100%" noShade SIZE=2>

<DIV style="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: always"></DIV><BR>

the long-term performance based plans for the years shown:</FONT></P>
<TABLE style="LINE-HEIGHT: 14pt; BORDER-COLLAPSE: collapse" cellSpacing=0 cellPadding=0 width="100%" border=0>

  <TR>
    <TD vAlign=top noWrap><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>*<STRONG><FONT size=1 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></STRONG></FONT></TD>

      later.</FONT></TD></TR></TABLE>
<P align=justify>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>At the
time of adopting new long-term plans, the Committee has made adjustments to the
percentage payouts for the components of the long-term plans to account for the
increasing difficulty of achieving compounded improvement.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT>The Committee anticipates adopting a
new plan each year, measuring improvement over successive three-year
periods.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT>The long-term performance based plan
adopted in 2011, which measured improvements through fiscal year 2013, paid out
in March 2014 and was calculated as follows:</FONT></P>
<TABLE style="LINE-HEIGHT: 14pt; BORDER-COLLAPSE: collapse" cellSpacing=0 cellPadding=0 width="100%" border=0>
